content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Browse online degrees section on Coursera and list 3 Bachelor's degree programmes.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current view is a promotional banner for Coursera Plus and doesn't have navigation or menu options to directly access the online degrees section. I need to scroll down to look for site navigation or links to the online degree programs.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is still no visible navigation or link to the online degrees section. More scrolling is needed to locate the bachelor's degree programs or a relevant menu.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible section highlights career skill specializations, not online degrees or Bachelor's programs. There may be more relevant links further down the page for online degrees or a dedicated degrees section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: A search bar is now visible, allowing keyword searches for programs. To directly find Bachelor's degree programs, I can use the search box with the keyword "bachelor."
Action: Type 2; bachelor
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search for "bachelor" has returned results, but the displayed items (e.g., "A+ Core 1 V15 - Pearson Cert Prep", "Data Science Fundamentals, Part 1") are specializations and not Bachelor's degree programs. I need to scroll down to look for Bachelor's degree programs or additional filter options.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The results displayed are still not Bachelor's degree programs; they are courses and specializations. I need to continue scrolling further down the search results to try to locate Bachelor's degree programs.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the section about Coursera Plus testimonials and frequently asked questions, which means I've scrolled past the search results without finding any Bachelor's degree programs. It seems the search results did not display Bachelor's degrees, likely due to filters or search term limitations. I need to try another approach, such as navigating to a dedicated "degrees" section, likely accessible from the main menu or via category filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am back at the previous search results, which still only show courses and specializations, not Bachelor's degrees. It confirms the keyword search did not yield degree programs. I need to find a way to access the category or filter specific to degrees, possibly from the homepage or main navigation.

Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search box is visible and there are filtering options by domain (e.g., Business, Computer Science, etc.), but still no specific option for degrees or Bachelor's degrees. Clearing the search and exploring the page for a more direct path to degree programs or a degrees category could be helpful.
Action: Click 2
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search field is clear, and domain buttons are available. There still isn't a clear filter or section directly for "degrees" or "Bachelor's degrees." It is possible that additional options or filters appear by scrolling further down or exploring more filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The results continue to display only specializations and individual courses, with no indication of degree programs, especially Bachelor's degrees. I still have not found an entry point or filter for online degrees. Further scrolling may reveal relevant sections or site navigation for degree programs.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the testimonial and FAQ section, indicating the bottom of the page or the end of the search/filter results, still without finding Bachelor's degree programs. The current search and filters approach is not yielding the required results. I need to return to the homepage or main navigation to look specifically for an "Online Degrees" or "Degrees" section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3

content.text:

Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.

content:
Thought: The search and domain filter results are only showing courses and specializations, not Bachelor's degree programs. There is no visible navigation here for the online degrees section. I should consider going back to the Coursera homepage to look for a dedicated "Degrees" or "Online Degrees" link in the main menu or footer.
Action: GoBack
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.35

Thought: The homepage is now visible. There is a section with three key options: "Launch a new career," "Gain in-demand skills," and "Earn a degree." Clicking "Earn a degree" is likely to lead to the online degrees section where I can find Bachelor's degree programs.
Action: Click 11
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.4

Thought: The "Earn a degree" section is now open. There are filter options for "Program Level" and "Subject," and I can already see a Bachelor's degree program listed ("Bachelor of Science in Computer Science"). To efficiently list Bachelor's degree programs, I should use the "Program Level" filter to show only Bachelor's degrees.
Action: Click 3
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.5
